document.masterDocTitle: New species and record of Pseudonereis (Annelida, Polychaeta, Nereididae) from Taiwan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and record of Pseudonereis (Annelida, Polychaeta, Nereididae) from Taiwan

bibRefCitation.author: Horst, R.
bibRefCitation.refString: Horst, R. (1924) Polychaeta errantia of the Siboga Expedition. Part III. Nereidae and Hesionidae. Siboga-Expeditie Uitkomsten op Zoologisch, Bonatisch, Oceanographisch en Geologisch gebied verzameld in Nederlandsch Oost-Indie 1899 - 1900, 24 (1 c), 145 - 198.

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 8A–F , 9A–F , 10A–E , 11A–C , 12A–F , 13A–F , 14A–F

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Nereis ( Pseudonereis ) trimaculata Horst 1924: 187–188
, pl. XXXVI, figs 8, 9. — Hartman 1959: 279.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pseudonereis rottnestiana
forma costatodentata Hartmann-Schröder 1979: 119, figs 220–222.

Material examined. Atoke:
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-26 ), Oldman Rock ( 22°0.3'N 121°34.7'E ), Lanyu Island , Taitung County , Taiwan , rocky intertidal habitats,
3 June 2006
;
2 specimens ( NMNS 8383-27 ), Jihuei ( 23°6.97'N 121°24.31'E ), Taitung County , Taiwan , rocky intertidal habitats,
14 October 2007
;
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-28 ), Jihuei , Taitung County ,
9 October 2010
;
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-29 ), Jihuei , Taitung County ,
27 March 2014
;
7 specimens ( NMNS 8383-28 – 30 ), Jihuei , Taitung County ,
27 September 2014
;
1 specimen ( NMNS 8383-31 ), Ji- huei, Taitung County ,
29 April 2017
;
5 specimens ( NMNS 8383-32 ), Jihuei , Taitung County ,
17 November 2019
;
5 specimens ( NMNS 8383-33 ), Kentin (( 20°54.7'N 121°50.8'E ), Pingtung County , Taiwan , rocky intertidal habitats,
17 October 2020
. Epitoke:
2 specimens ( NMNS 8383-34 ), Jihuei ( 23°6.97'N 121°24.31'E ), Taitung County , rocky intertidal habitats,
17 November 2019
.

Description. Atoke: Based on specimen NMNS 8383-29, complete, body length 35.5 mm with 83 chaetigers, chaetiger 10 width 1.5 mm , excluding parapodia; beige in alcohol ( Fig. 8A ). Specimens NMNS 8383-26–27, 33 with pharynx everted and used for illustrating paragnath patterns and shape of ridge pattern in Areas VI–V–VI of the pharynx.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Pseudonereis trimaculata Horst, 1924
; A, specimen NMNS 8383-29, B–C, specimen NMNS 8383-26, D, speci- men NMNS 8383-33, E–F, specimen NMNS 8383-27: A, anterior body, dorsal view; B, paragnaths of the pharynx, dorsal view; C, paragnaths of the pharynx, frontal view; D, anterior body, dorsal view; E, paragnaths of the pharynx, dorsal view; F, parag- naths of the pharynx, ventral view. Scale: A, D, 1.0 mm; B–C, E–F, 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Pygidium crenulated; anal cirri cirriform, as long as last 5 chaetigers.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Pseudonereis trimaculata Horst, 1924
; specimen NMNS 8383-29: A, right parapodium, anterior view, chaetiger 11; B, right parapodium, posterior view, chaetiger 11; C, right parapodium, chaetiger 35; D, right parapodium, chaetiger 50; E, right parapodium, chaetiger 60; F, right parapodium, chaetiger 76. Abbreviation: NeIA, neuroacicular inferior lobe; NePL, neuropodial postchaetal lobe; NeSA, neuroacicular superior lobe. Scale: A–F, 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Longest tentacular cirrus reached chaetiger 3–10 (n= 20). Apodous anterior segment ranged about 1.3-1.6 (n= 10) times longer than chaetiger 1. Number of lateral teeth on cutting edge of the jaws ranged 5–10 (n= 22). Paragnath numbers in Area II ranged 29–49 (left) and 18–46 (right) in 4–5 rows (n= 22), Area III 54–91 in 3–5 rows (n= 22), Area IV 36–93 (left) and 44–112 (right) in 5 rows (n= 22), Area V 1–2 (n= 22), Area VII–VIII 22–30 (n= 22), respectively. Heterogomph spinigers in the subacicular fascicle of the neuropodia commenced on chaetiger 37–41 (n=2). Length of anal cirri cirriform ranged from as long as last 5–10 chaetigers (n= 6).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Pseudonereis trimaculata Horst, 1924
; specimen NMNS 8383-29: A, notochaeta, homogomph spiniger, chaetiger 18; B, supra-acicular homogomph spiniger, chaetiger 45; C, supra-acicular short-bladed heterogomph falciger, chaetiger 45; D, subacicular heterogomph spiniger, chaetiger 45; E, subacicular short-bladed heterogomph falciger, chaetiger 45. Scale: A–E, 0.01 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Male epitoke (specimen NMNS 8383-34 (2)) has digitiform dorsal cirri commenced on chaetiger 7. Dorsal cirrus lobe has not expanded to lamellae on any chaetiger. Neuropodial postchaetal lobe has not broadly expanded and always shorter than median ligule. Parapodial chaetae have not been replaced by natatory chaetae in the natatory body region ( Fig. 14A–F ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11.
Pseudonereis trimaculata Horst, 1924
; specimen NMNS 8383-35, epitoke, female: A, whole animal; B, anterior body, dorsal view; C, paragnaths of the pharynx, ventral view. Scale: A, 5.0 mm; B, 1.0 mm; C, 0.5 mm.

FIGURE 12.
Pseudonereis trimaculata Horst, 1924
; specimen NMNS 8383-35, epitoke, female: A, right parapodium, chaeti- ger 4; B, right parapodium, chaetiger 11; C, right parapodium, chaetiger 14; D, right parapodium, chaetiger 17; E, right para- podium, anterior view, chaetiger 54; F, right parapodium, anterior view, chaetiger 85. Abbreviation: DC, dorsal cirrus; DCLo, dorsal cirrus lobe; DCLa, dorsal cirrus lamellae; NeIA, neuropodial inferior acicular lobe; NePLa, neuropodial postchaetal lamellae; NeSA, neuropodial superior acicular lobe; NeVL, neuropodial ventral ligule; NoDL, notopodial dorsal ligule; NoVL, notopodial ventral ligule; VC; ventral cirrus; VCLa, ventral cirrus lamellae; VCLo, ventral cirrus lobe. Scale: A–L, 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Geser, Indonesia , Western Australia, eastern and southern Taiwan .

Remarks. The present species is similar to
P. trimaculata
in term of paragnath patterns of the pharynx, morphology of parapodia, presence of glands on all three ligules of in most of chaetigers, and chaetal patterns ( Bakken 2007: 167–168 , fig. 13A–E; Figs 8B–C , 9A–F , 10A–E , Table 1 ). However, minor variations are noted between the present specimens and
P. trimaculata
: 1) the present specimens have a range of 1 to 3 conical paragnaths in Area V of the pharynx (versus 3); and 2) no blacks spots on parapodia in fresh specimens of the present study (versus pres- ence of black spots). Bakken (2007) stated that those spots are glands commonly seen in parapodia of nereidids, but now vaguely visible in the lectotype .

Epitokes of
P. trimaculata
are described for the first time in the present study. Different sexes show significant differences in morphological modifications. The female epitoke has a greater number of chaetigers and greater degree of morphological modifications on these chaetigers than that of the male epitoke. These morphological differences include that the female epitoke has: 1) about 90% (versus about 50%) of chaetigers with at least some degree of morphological modifications; 2) a dorsal small lobe on notopodial ligules and neuropodial ligule on modi- fied chaetigers (versus absent); 3) well-developed of dorsal cirrus lamellae, neuropodial postchaetal lamellae, and neuropodial ventral cirrus lobe and lamellae on the corresponding body segments (versus all moderate developed); 4) natatory chaetae on natatory body region (versus absent); and 5) different arrangement of notochaetae and neu- rochaetae on natatory body region than that of atokous individuals (versus similar arrangement) ( Figs 11–14 ).
